metadata.title: Find time for all your side projects | by Ane Berasategi | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Find time for all your side projects
metadata.description: Find time for programming or coding side projects, reserve minimum time to make some progress on each task. Have a short to do list with your goals and start small.

all_paragraphs: If you’re like me, you have a long list of things you’d like to do, but you never find time to start with them. These can be anything from coding projects to household ideas, playing an instrument, writing, reading, working out.
Any habit that you wish you did regularly but you don’t start because they would take up many hours per week and you don’t have that kind of time.

If you’re already efficient with your time and don’t have any time left in your week, you don’t need this post. You clearly spend your time as you want and have no time left for side projects, and that’s totally fine.
But if you have project ideas, tend to procrastinate, sometimes feel like you don’t know where the time went, or in general feel like you could be spending your time better, read on :)

What are my qualifications to be talking about time management? I’m no productivity expert (because there’s no such thing), but I’ve been managing my time and productivity for years and I’ve found a system that works very well for me and for some people I’ve recommended it to. I’ll make another post about that if there’s interest.

But one of the struggles I’ve had is finding time for side projects, which ideally I’d spend many hours per week on and of course I don’t have time. So they kept accumulating, until some months ago I decided to try something.
In my particular case, these were my potential side projects:

As you can see, this is a lot on top of my already busy schedule with uni, work, and life. Previously, I’d tackle one of them, but they’re very long (the first two especially), reading papers is a never-ending task, things would get in the way and I’d stop. So this is what I thought.
I can find 1h a week for algorithms, 1h a week for freecodecamp, I can read one paper a week.

I thought: what’s the minimum time I can spend with any of these tasks so that I can do some small progress and still be satisfied? In my case, usually, 1h is enough for an exercise, or the majority of it. One paper a week is doable. 15mins a day playing the flute is good enough.

Spending so little time with the algorithm book means I won’t finish it in months, I won’t finish the freecodecamp curriculum in months, same with my paper list, but none of this is urgent. And this way, each week, I’m doing small progress in many different things.
Allocate the minimum amount of time necessary to make small but meaningful progress in your project.
Now, how do we do that?
I’d advise you to write a list of side projects you’d like to start with. Go through them and allocate the minimum time a week you’re comfortable with.

30min/week writing, 1 exercise/week, 5min/day reading, 5min/day working out, make it so little time that it seems it’s nothing. The more you struggle with it, the less time you put. Surely you can do it for 5 minutes, whatever it is! After that, you can stop and feel accomplished. And who knows, maybe after you start you’ll want to do more.
I have a file on my computer because I change many things throughout the week, but you can do it in a notebook as well.

Have a ‘to do’ list in your file/sheet with clearly defined tasks, either time or content. Each night before bed review it and think: which of these things can I accomplish tomorrow? Will I have a busy day or more relaxed? Where can I find the time? Mark those tasks somehow, and be realistic.
The following day, make it your mission to do the 5 or 30 mins of those tasks. Before breakfast, during your break, when you feel like you’re procrastinating. Just do them, they don’t take very long.
At night, whether you managed to do them or not, sit down again and reevaluate. Move the tasks you did to another list like ‘done’, and mark the tasks you think you can do tomorrow again.

During the week, you’ll be moving more tasks to the ‘done’ list. On Sunday evening, maybe you’ll have an empty ‘to do’ list, or maybe not. Review your week, are you satisfied with it? Did you procrastinate a lot? Could you have done those remaining tasks somehow? Update the ‘to do’ list for next week, and don’t put too many things.

Important: there is no failing with this system, you’re on this journey with yourself. If you feel you can’t do more, then you can’t do more. No one is watching, this is just for you. If you don’t finish your list, delete some items. Start small, experiment.

It’s incredibly satisfying to see an (almost) empty ‘to do’ list and a packed ‘done’ list on Sunday. But more importantly, it feels fantastic to be doing some progress with all these projects, however small. Because something is better than nothing.

I encourage you to try the idea of this method, change it as you wish to make it work for you, and don’t overwork yourself. I started some months ago, some weeks are busier than others but I’m making steady progress and I couldn’t be happier.
If you want to tell me how you’re doing or chat with me about anything, you can find me on twitter. Thanks for reading!
